unnormalised: What's the deal with all these abbreviations people use online these days? Like, what does "IMHO" even mean? And why does everyone keep saying "lol"? It's all so confusing! My nephew uses these all the time. He keeps saying "BRB" when he goes to get chai. Feels like I need a dictionary just to understand him.
normalised: What's the deal with all these abbreviations people use online these days? Like, what does "I-M-H-O" even mean? And why does everyone keep saying "L-O-L"? It's all so confusing! My nephew uses these all the time. He keeps saying "B-R-B" when he goes to get chai. Feels like I need a dictionary just to understand him.

unnormalised: Well, fret not, uncle ji! "IMHO" stands for "In My Humble Opinion." It's a polite way of expressing your view. "LOL" simply means "Laughing Out Loud," used when something's funny, even if you're not actually laughing. These originated in the early days of internet chatrooms and forums where typing speed was crucial, so people naturally shortened phrases. Think of it as the shorthand of the digital world.
normalised: Well, fret not, uncle ji! "I-M-H-O" stands for "In My Humble Opinion." It's a polite way of expressing your view. "L-O-L" simply means "Laughing Out Loud," used when something's funny, even if you're not actually laughing. These originated in the early days of internet chatrooms and forums where typing speed was crucial, so people naturally shortened phrases. Think of it as the shorthand of the digital world.

unnormalised: There are loads more! You'll often see "FYI" which is "For Your Information". Then you have "IDK" meaning "I Don't Know". "TBH" is "To Be Honest" and "TBD" which is "To Be Determined." Acronyms and initialisms are super common because they save time and effort when typing, especially on mobile phones. SMS language was the grandfather of this.
normalised: There are loads more! You'll often see "F-Y-I" which is "For Your Information". Then you have "I-D-K" meaning "I Don't Know". "T-B-H" is "To Be Honest" and "T-B-D" which is "To Be Determined." Acronyms and initialisms are super common because they save time and effort when typing, especially on mobile phones. S-M-S language was the grandfather of this.

unnormalised: You might also encounter "AFK" (Away From Keyboard) when someone's stepping away from their computer, or "IRL" (In Real Life) when discussing something outside of the digital space. Another one is "DM" (Direct Message), which means to privately message someone. Learning these acronyms helps in navigating online conversations and understanding internet culture. You will find them everywhere from email subject lines to Twitter posts.
normalised: You might also encounter "A-F-K" (Away From Keyboard) when someone's stepping away from their computer, or "I-R-L" (In Real Life) when discussing something outside of the digital space. Another one is "D-M" (Direct Message), which means to privately message someone. Learning these acronyms helps in navigating online conversations and understanding internet culture. You will find them everywhere from email subject lines to Twitter posts.

unnormalised: So next time your nephew says "BRB," you'll know he's just popping out for a quick chai break! Understanding these abbreviations will make you a pro at navigating the digital world, and you'll be able to keep up with the online Gen Z conversation. Happy surfing!
normalised: So next time your nephew says "B-R-B," you'll know he's just popping out for a quick chai break! Understanding these abbreviations will make you a pro at navigating the digital world, and you'll be able to keep up with the online G-en Z conversation. Happy surfing!
